thread.title: British Muslim teacher booted off NY plane despite visa
thread.title_full: British Muslim teacher booted off NY plane despite visa

author: ELIZABETH ELIZALDE
title: British Muslim teacher booted off NY plane despite visa
text:
British Muslim teacher booted off New York bound plane despite having visa, says he felt 'like a criminal' British Muslim teacher with valid visa booted off N.Y. plane It's unclear if Trump's travel ban was the reason a British Muslim teacher was removed from a plane in Iceland headed for New York. The teacher had a valid visa. (Evan Vucci/AP) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  22 PM 
A British Muslim teacher traveling with his students from Iceland to New York was denied entry to the United States despite having a valid visa, according to a report. 
Juhel Miah, of Neath Port Talbot, Wales, and his students from Llangatwg Community School boarded a flight from Reykjavik, Iceland to New York on Feb. 16, but he was suddenly escorted off the plane by security without an explanation, Britain’s Wales Online reported . 
“It made me feel like a criminal,” Miah, who local authorities say has a valid travel visa, told the website . “I couldn’t speak, I was lost for words.” 
Miah’s removal left his students “shocked and distressed,” but the school trip continued as planned. — South Wales EP (@SWEveningPost) February 20, 2017 
The 25-year-old who’s described as a “popular and respected teacher” at the school was also denied access to the U.S. Embassy in Iceland. 
Neath Port Talbot County Borough Council has written to the U.S. Embassy in London condemning its treatment of Miah. 
"Mr. Miah attempted to visit the Embassy; but was denied access to the building,” a council spokesman said. “Understandably he feels belittled and upset at what appears to be an unjustified act of discrimination.” Juhel Miah, 25, teaches at Llangatwg Community School in Aberdulais, Wales. (Google Maps Street View) 
Trump's revised travel ban will target same 7 Muslim countries 
Reasons for Miah’s removal or if his situation resulted from President Trump’s travel ban remain unclear. 
The President’s executive order prohibits people from seven-predominately Muslim countries from entering the U.S., but the federal courts stalled it amid massive protests nationwide opposing the action. 
The Trump administration is expected to announce a revised travel ban sometime this week. Join the Conversation:
